@joeymcallister @davebarnes97 @karensmolermiller would one of you or some of you be able to review this, I don't have permissions to add you as reviewers, but I would like your review.

I think it is still worth adding a test that demonstrates that this class is now thread safe.
You have made it so by making it immutable but the test would prove that it actually is immutable.
And the test could catch future regressions if someone breaks the immutable contract.
@nvpivot I have some language changes, not sure how best to submit them. Can pair with you to discuss.

could you help me with running of benchmark. I can run it locally, but for compare local branch to base, I need to set AWS keys..

Thanks

```
ERROR: (gcloud.compute.instances.create) Could not fetch resource:
 - Internal error. Please try again or contact Google Support. (Code: '-1396745325018209338')
```
Retriggering precheckin should hopefully clear this up.
@BenjaminPerryRoss

My concern at the moment is... what if a client app has a function compiled against the old cq api.  Would they have to recompile against the new source?  If so, that would be forcing the client app to upgrade which kind of defeats the purpose of being backwards compatible.

> @nvpivot I have some language changes, not sure how best to submit them. Can pair with you to discuss.

Made my edits in place, totaling several commits. Mostly trivial changes from future to present tense and formatting changes.
I did remove the invitation to request additional meters via pull requests - this is an open source repo, so I think that's understood. There are no other examples of this elsewhere in the user guide.

Thanks again to all involved for a cool new feature set and for providing documentation!

We also keep it as a separate resource in the PR pipeline so that we don't
run random unmerged scripts in our CI infrastructure.

On Fri, Nov 1, 2019, 09:37 Owen Nichols <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> *@onichols-pivotal* commented on this pull request.
>
> This change seems fine. However, I wonder if we could go a step further
> and eliminate having geode-ci as a separate resource entirely. The
> historical reason for having it separate, was to allow latest scripts in ci
> to be used independently of the geode SHA. However, more in the last year
> it has been changed to have the same passing constraints as the geode
> resource, so it is effectively identical. We could just search and replace
> geode-ci/ci to geode/ci and get rid of this resource entirely.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/4262?email_source=notifications&email_token=AHVPPUVQJKSQINMH2Z63A33QRRLOHA5CNFSM4JHQOTM2YY3PNVWWK3TUL52HS4DFWFIHK3DMKJSXC5LFON2FEZLWNFSXPKTDN5WW2ZLOORPWSZGOCKBNBFQ#pullrequestreview-310562966>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AHVPPUVHSJUKF4WDDCM22HLQRRLOHANCNFSM4JHQOTMQ>
> .
>
that is a good point!  please disregard my suggestion to combine geode+geode_ci
@jmelchio check out the use of `premailer` to inline the CSS now!

> I think it is still worth adding a test that demonstrates that this class is now thread safe.
> You have made it so by making it immutable but the test would prove that it actually is immutable.
> And the test could catch future regressions if someone breaks the immutable contract.

I have been thinking about what test(s) I could add but have not come up with any idea.

Regarding SSLConfig, after the changes it does not offer any public method that would allow to modify its state. It only provides the constructor and getter methods so I cannot think of a test that would assure that in the future the class will remain immutable.

Regarding SSLConfigurationFactory, having removed the deprecated method that returned shared SSLConfig objects (stored in the static HashMap member), now it always returns a new SSLConfig object each time the getSSLConfigForComponent method is invoked.
In this case, the only test case I can think of is one that makes sure that invocations of these methods with the same parameters return different objects. Would this be useful?

I'd appreciate any insight on what tests to add.

Thanks in advance.

I you went back to the initial condition (before this pr's work) wouldn't you be able to write a concurrent test that demonstrates that these classes are not thread safe? If so, then that test should start passing with this pr's changes.

> I you went back to the initial condition (before this pr's work) wouldn't you be able to write a concurrent test that demonstrates that these classes are not thread safe? If so, then that test should start passing with this pr's changes.

The fact is that the method that had thread-safety issues (public static SSLConfig getSSLConfigForComponent(SecurableCommunicationChannel sslEnabledComponent)) has been eliminated.
Therefore, I could use in a test prior to the PR to see failures but I could not in the new version as it would not be present.

> @BenjaminPerryRoss : I think there's still no definitive answer to [this discussion](https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/4161#discussion_r339060678) within the PR. Thoughts?.

This has now been addressed. Any exception encountered in the `updateMethodAuthorizer()` method during cache creation now results a `QueryConfigurationServiceException` being thrown and creation being aborted.
Tests failing..
Fixed issues with pull request.
Adding more tests

> My concern at the moment is... what if a client app has a function compiled against the old cq api. Would they have to recompile against the new source? If so, that would be forcing the client app to upgrade which kind of defeats the purpose of being backwards compatible.
Do you mean a function that in the execute method creates a continuous query? Does that make sense? I thought CQs were to be run by clients on its servers.

On my side I am not sure if I understand how your changes in the tests have gotten rid of the NoSuchMethod exception.
Is it because the client code is compiled against the old cq API version but it is linked with the new version of the cq API when it is executed?
@albertogpz I have cherry-picked your commits and I think I've got everything fixed here. Please review.
dang it! `LocatorLauncherStatusTest` is failing. I reproduced it on my laptop.
ok @jinmeiliao helped me fix the failing `LocatorLauncherStatusTest` 🤞

I know that I am VERY late into this discussion... I think the essence of WHY has been lost be this refactor. Whilst approving code on correctness of code is good, but context is lacking and thus we have now added a new potential performance issue. Given that there is no documentation as to what the constraints are/were initially this fix is good.

But to fill in the gaps in context:

1. `SSLConfigurationFactory` was supposed to cache `SSLConfig` objects, for performance reasons. This has now been lost. In addition we are now adding more time in processing the `DistributionConfig` EVERY time we need `SSLConfig` for a `SecurableChannel`
1. The `DistributionConfig` stored on the `SSLConfigurationFactory` was really to tie the "cached" `SSLConfig` objects to a `DistributionConfig`
1. `SSLConfigurationFactory` was never supposed to be static. At the time we had to do it, because we could not find a good "home" for it. It should really be an instance that takes a `DistributionConfig` and provides the `SSLConfig` for that config. Not an ad-hoc.
1. Thread safety is really less of a concern, given that the `DistributionConfig` should never change throughout the lifetime of the `DistributedSystem`. If you happen to have 10 threads asking for `SSLConfig` for the `SERVER` at the same time, YES, you could have 10 threads recreating the same 10 `SSLConfig`urations, BUT, they would contain the SAME information. In the end you will 1 cached copy of `SSLConfig`.

I think DO like the new `SSLConfig.Builder` pattern applied now. Immutability of the `SSLConfig` object is great! Maybe, if we can couple, it would "caching" we might be able to offset the performance hit we would now have.

It is also interesting to me that we annotate `final` properties with `Immutable`.

> I know that I am VERY late into this discussion... I think the essence of WHY has been lost be this refactor. Whilst approving code on correctness of code is good, but context is lacking and thus we have now added a new potential performance issue. Given that there is no documentation as to what the constraints are/were initially this fix is good.

If you happen to have 10 threads asking for `SSLConfig` for the `SERVER` at the same time, YES, you could have 10 threads recreating the same 10 `SSLConfig`urations, BUT, they would contain the SAME information. In the end you will 1 cached copy of `SSLConfig`.

> 
> It is also interesting to me that we annotate `final` properties with `Immutable`.

Hi Udo,
I noticed that this class was providing a cache for SSLConfig objects. Nevertheless, the method that was making use of the cache appeared as deprecated since Geode 1.3. In the comment, about the deprecation, it was recommended to use another method of the class that created an SSLConfig each time.
Given that the cache had some thread-safety issues to be solved and given that the method managing the was deprecated I figured the best option would be to just remove it.
Anyway, if it was a mistake to remove it, I offer myself to put it back.

@albertogpz Thank you for this.
I think there are some good fixes in the PR. I think we need the `SSLConfig` cache back.. but it needs to be better managed. Possibly there is some stale state and possibly some better approaches to some of the deficiencies.

I had not noticed the deprecation on the method. Possibly another commit that did not take into account the "caching".

Tbh, let's see how this evolves, maybe "cache vs not cached" is a non-event given that we don't really cycle connections that often.

Thank you for the PR though. Great work!

The tests are compiled with the new method signature and the test will execute the test code on the old servers which had the old method signature.  The fix was to use reflection to grab the correct method/method signature and do it at runtime instead of compile time.

Two potential problems:
1.) The problem now is if a client application that is compiled against the old signature, attempts to run the compiled code on a new server.. 

2.) If this change is just client side changes, then this would only be an issue if they update the geode jar without recompiling the client...
I did some repeated testing and this fix looks good.
This PR was approved 28 days ago. Is it ready for be merged?

> This PR was approved 28 days ago. Is it ready for be merged?

Ok, I have just seen there are conflicts, Im going to fix them

> The tests are compiled with the new method signature and the test will execute the test code on the old servers which had the old method signature. The fix was to use reflection to grab the correct method/method signature and do it at runtime instead of compile time.
> 
> Two potential problems:
> 1.) The problem now is if a client application that is compiled against the old signature, attempts to run the compiled code on a new server..
> 
> 2.) If this change is just client side changes, then this would only be an issue if they update the geode jar without recompiling the client...

The way I see it (please, correct me if I am wrong) is that the method modified is only run on the client.
If this is so, the test is doing something strange: It compiles the client with the new library but then runs the client with the old one. That's why you needed to use reflection to get the right version of the method.
I think clients should be expected to be recompiled if the geode library is updated.
Closing this PR while I fix this failing stress test.
Given the lack of interest for this feature, I am closing this PR without merging.
@jmelchio
Three JDK 11 jobs fail repeatedly with NPEs, which appear to be thrown in gradle or the test runner, not in the tests themselves.  I suspect I have neglected some secret Gradle incantation.

I think you understand how this specific test is running.
I am not sure if we can expect a user to recompile a client whenever a server gets upgraded (which is why we have backwards compatible clients)
In this specific case, if the api is only used on client side, then this change is probably a safe change.  Maybe we can ask the user list to see if anyone used the cq attributes in a function on the server.

@upthewaterspout we've historically had issues modifying apis and compiled application code. 
I am not sure if this brings back any memories or if you know whether this change definitely will break a certain use case... I would think cq's are primarily created on clients and none of that code would be sent to the server...
We could just bump the limit too.
I don't have that power, but if you do, I will be happy to amend this PR to correspond to 1/12 of the new quota.
Since there is no progress on this PR, I will close it.

> Actually I don't think we should make initlalize default method

@jhuynh1 It's possible for a user-defined authorizer to not need to implement the `initialize()` method, for example, if the configuration for the authorizer is fixed and does not need parameters in order to perform authorizations. For this reason, it would be preferable not to force users to implement the `initialize()` method by making it non-default.
@jinmeiliao @onichols-pivotal @dschneider-pivotal @dhemery
looks like ManagementRequestLoggingDistributedTest needs to be updated
closing so CI doesn't run
@jmelchio

> I've made some minor comments on the code and I have a bigger one, probably too late to implement but will throw it here anyway, though: the whole PR uses names like `query-config-service` for `XML` and `QueryConfigurationService*` for classes, which seems a bit confusing to me... wouldn't it be better to change this naming `query-service` / `query-service-config` and `QueryServiceConfiguration` instead as it was in the [original proposal](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/GEODE/OQL+Method+Invocation+Security#OQLMethodInvocationSecurity-ConfigurationOptions)?. I believe it better reflects the intent of the feature.

We wanted to avoid confusing between the QueryService (the previously existing service) and our new Service class which configures it. We also wanted to maintain the naming pattern used by other cache services, which end with the term 'Service'. We feel the most accurate name would be "QueryServiceConfigurationService" as it is a service which configures the query service, but truncated it to QueryConfigurationService as we felt the full name sounded a bit wordy and confusing. For now we plan to leave this as it is but if the naming becomes an issue we can always create a new PR to change it.
We have some jobs (StressNewTest) that are getting close to the 6 hour mark, so lets bump the instance-reaper out to 12h
This branch had an approved PR a week or so ago. But I've fiddled with it a lot since then, to get the stress test passing, so thought it was appropriate to ask for a fresh sign-off.

@mhansonp That's correct. All but one test in the DistributedTest used a single JVM so I extracted those to create the new IntegrationTest.
I'm adding a few reviewers who might have some additional insight/opinion on this area
@jmelchio
It looks like GEODE-7445 does not need to be reverted

I think we have previously decided that breaking binary compatibility counts as breaking backwards compatibility. 

Here's a discussion thread where this came up previously:
https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/ebdeabc24ce0ff418427021dfbbd45aceb51939f25de4aba7bb5c97b@%3Cdev.geode.apache.org%3E

I think maintaining binary compatibility is important because the person upgrading geode may not always be able to recompile the source - for example when using a third party library based on geode.
thanks @bschuchardt  and @upthewaterspout !!
@agingade: Thats great. Do you want to push test to this branch?
@Bill  - Made the changes you requested. Please rereview.

I looked into doing this. There aren't actually a lot of unit tests that create a CacheClientNotifier, so I don't think it would be too hard to add After tasks to reset them. I would still keep this change, though, in case a new test create a CacheClientNotifier but didn't reset it.

> @bschuchardt @pivotal-jbarrett Are there still concerns with this PR?

My concern over the threadConnectionMap null checks hasn't been addressed.  I've been fighting against the nulling-out of instance variables like this forever.  It's always causing NPEs for unsuspecting programmers who don't recognize that this anti-pattern is being used.  The instance variable ought to be "final" and some other state should be added and consulted to see if the connection table has been closed.
@jmelchio
